title: Ruth and Boaz
shortSummary: In Ruth chapter 2, Ruth begins gleaning in the fields of Boaz, a wealthy kinsman of Naomi's late husband. Boaz shows kindness and protection toward Ruth, recognizing her loyalty and faith, which sets the stage for God's providential care and redemption.
timeline: c. 1100 BC - Period of the Judges

keyCharacters.name: Ruth
keyCharacters.description: A Moabitess widow who loyally follows Naomi and seeks provision by gleaning in the fields.

keyCharacters.name: Boaz
keyCharacters.description: A wealthy and honorable kinsman of Elimelech, Naomi’s deceased husband, who shows kindness and protection to Ruth.

keyCharacters.name: Naomi
keyCharacters.description: Widow of Elimelech and mother-in-law to Ruth, who guides Ruth in seeking provision and recognizes Boaz’s role as a kinsman-redeemer.

keyCharacters.name: Boaz’s Servants
keyCharacters.description: The young men who work in Boaz’s fields and obey his instructions to protect and provide for Ruth.

definitions.definition: The practice of collecting leftover grain or produce from the fields after the main harvest, allowed by Mosaic Law to provide for the poor and foreigners.
A close relative who has the responsibility to protect and redeem family members, especially in matters of inheritance and marriage.
A Hebrew unit of dry measure, approximately equivalent to 22 liters or about half a bushel.

definitions.term: Under whose wings thou art come to trust
definitions.definition: A Hebrew metaphor expressing refuge and protection under God’s care.

outline.heading: Introduction of Boaz, the Kinsman
outline.description: Naomi’s relative Boaz is introduced as a wealthy man of the family of Elimelech. Ruth seeks permission to glean in the fields and by God’s providence ends up in Boaz’s field.

outline.heading: Boaz’s Kindness to Ruth
outline.description: Boaz greets his workers and inquires about Ruth. Upon learning of her loyalty to Naomi, he blesses her and offers protection and provision, recognizing her faith and character.

outline.heading: Provision and Protection in the Field
outline.description: Boaz invites Ruth to share a meal with his workers and commands his men to leave extra grain for her, ensuring she can glean safely and abundantly.

outline.heading: Ruth’s Harvest and Naomi’s Blessing
outline.description: Ruth gathers about an ephah of barley and returns to Naomi, who rejoices in God’s kindness through Boaz and encourages Ruth to continue gleaning under his protection until the harvest is complete.

application: Trust God’s providence in difficult circumstances, as Ruth did by seeking work and relying on His guidance.
Show kindness and protection to those in need, following Boaz’s example of generosity and care.
Remain faithful and diligent in obedience to God’s commands, even in humble tasks like gleaning.
Recognize and honor God’s hand of blessing in relationships and provision.

keyVerses.text: The LORD recompense thy work, and a full reward be given thee of the LORD God of Israel, under whose wings thou art come to trust.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights God’s protective care and promises blessing to those who trust in Him.

keyVerses.text: Then said Boaz unto Ruth, Hearest thou not, my daughter? Go not to glean in another field, neither go from hence, but abide here fast by my maidens:
keyVerses.significance: Boaz’s protective command shows his kindness and the security God provides through faithful people.

keyVerses.text: And Naomi said unto her daughter in law, Blessed be he of the LORD, who hath not left off his kindness to the living and to the dead. And Naomi said unto her, The man is near of kin unto us, one of our next kinsmen.
keyVerses.significance: Naomi recognizes God’s ongoing kindness and introduces the theme of redemption through kinship.
